Use ## for comments and # for configuration. ## The following names are reserved and should not be used (or ignored): ## id, tooltip, placeholder(s), link and label (see below) ## # ## Node label with placeholders and HTML. ## Default is '%name_of_first_column%'. # # label: %name%
%position%
Email # ## Node style (placeholders are replaced once). ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # style: label;image=%image%;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;rounded=1;fillColor=%fill%;strokeColor=%stroke%; # ## Parent style for nodes with child nodes (placeholders are replaced once). # # parentstyle: swimlane;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1; # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named style in styles. ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # stylename: - # ## JSON for named styles of the form {"name": "style", "name": "style"} where style is a cell style with ## placeholders that are replaced once. # # styles: - # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named label in labels. ## Default is the current label. # # labelname: - # ## JSON for named labels of the form {"name": "label", "name": "label"} where label is a cell label with ## placeholders. # # labels: - # ## Uses the given column name as the identity for cells (updates existing cells). ## Default is no identity (empty value or -). # # identity: - # ## Uses the given column name as the parent reference for cells. Default is no parent (empty or -). ## The identity above is used for resolving the reference so it must be specified. # # parent: - # ## Adds a prefix to the identity of cells to make sure they do not collide with existing cells (whose ## IDs are numbers from 0..n, sometimes with a GUID prefix in the context of realtime collaboration). ## Default is csvimport-. # # namespace: csvimport- # ## Connections between rows ("from": source colum, "to": target column). ## Label, style and invert are optional. Defaults are '', current style and false. ## If placeholders are used in the style, they are replaced with data from the source. ## An optional placeholders can be set to target to use data from the target instead. ## In addition to label, an optional fromlabel and tolabel can be used to name the column ## that contains the text for the label in the edges source or target (invert ignored). ## The label is concatenated in the form fromlabel + label + tolabel if all are defined. ## The target column may contain a comma-separated list of values. ## Multiple connect entries are allowed. # # connect: {"from": "manager", "to": "name", "invert": true, "label": "manages", \ # "style": "curved=1;endArrow=blockThin;endFill=1;fontSize=11;"} # connect: {"from": "refs", "to": "id", "style": "curved=1;fontSize=11;"} # ## Node x-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # left: # ## Node y-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # top: # ## Node width. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the width. Default is auto. # # width: auto # ## Node height. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the height. Default is auto. # # height: auto # ## Padding for autosize. Default is 0. # # padding: -12 # ## Comma-separated list of ignored columns for metadata. (These can be ## used for connections and styles but will not be added as metadata.) # # ignore: id,image,fill,stroke,refs,manager # ## Column to be renamed to link attribute (used as link). # # link: url # ## Spacing between nodes. Default is 40. # # nodespacing: 40 # ## Spacing between levels of hierarchical layouts. Default is 100. # # levelspacing: 100 # ## Spacing between parallel edges. Default is 40. Use 0 to disable. # # edgespacing: 40 # ## Name or JSON of layout. Possible values are auto, none, verticaltree, horizontaltree, ## verticalflow, horizontalflow, organic, circle or a JSON string as used in Layout, Apply. ## Default is auto. # # layout: auto # ## ---- CSV below this line. options.content: UCS Domain Traffic - $domain_name (IP $domain) located in $domain_location

panels.description:
Combined Inbound and outbound Ethernet traffic on UCS Domain 

![Domain Traffic Overview](/public/img/utm/domain_traffic_overview.png)

targets.query: SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth' AND "channel" != '') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time([[__interval_ms]]ms),transport fill(linear)

SELECT sum("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth' AND "channel" != '') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time([[__interval_ms]]ms),transport fill(linear)

panels.title: Ethernet Traffic - Total  - $domain

panels.title: Top 10 RX utilization - FI Uplink ports - FC

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find uplink port utilization (% and bits/s) and the servers that are sending/receiving traffic over that uplink port. Did you receive high utilization or congestion alert on an uplink port and you want to know what caused it? Look here to find the top-talker server(s) that contributed most to the uplink utilization.

![Uplink port traffic per server](/public/img/utm/uplink_port_traffic_per_server.png)

**How to use**:  Select a UCS domain, FI (A or B) and an *Uplink* (Not the *Uplink Port Channel*). The RX and TX traffic graphs are auto-generated side-by-side along with the traffic breakdown per server. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of uplink. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - Displayed service profiles have vNIC/vHBA pinned to this uplink and hence, contributing to the traffic on this port.
  - Click on legends to sort according to the utilization.

You can select more than one value or All from *Uplink*. Looking at everything together can be useful when you don't know where to start or while doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one uplink at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: 
  - The displayed uplink utilization is slightly higher (1.1x) than the sum of the utilization of all servers to prevent overlapping in the graph. You can safely ignore this observation.
  - It is possible to display the traffic breakdown per vNIC/vHBA but that will make this graph too busy. Traffic breakdown at per vNIC/vHBA level is available on the page dedicated for server monitoring.

targets.query: SELECT (mean("bytes_rx_delta")  *8*1.1/[[polling_interval]])/(mean("oper_speed")*1000000000) AS "RX % Util" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "port" =~ /^$uplink$/ AND "fi_id" =~ /^$fi_id$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "port" fill(linear)

SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/[[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "pinned_uplink" =~ /^$uplink$/ AND "fi_id" =~ /^$fi_id$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time([[__interval_ms]]ms), "service_profile" fill(linear)

SELECT last("oper_speed")  *1000000000 AS "RX Util MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "port" =~ /^$uplink$/ AND "fi_id" =~ /^$fi_id$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "port" fill(linear)

SELECT last("oper_speed")/last("oper_speed") AS "RX % MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "port" =~ /^$uplink$/ AND "fi_id" =~ /^$fi_id$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "port" fill(linear)

SELECT (mean("bytes_rx_delta")  *8*1.1/[[polling_interval]]) AS "RX Util" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "port" =~ /^$uplink$/ AND "fi_id" =~ /^$fi_id$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "port" fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-$fi_id $uplink traffic breakdown - TX

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find uplink port utilization (% and bits/s) and the servers that are sending/receiving traffic over that uplink port. Did you receive high utilization or congestion alert on an uplink port and you want to know what caused it? Look here to find the top-talker server(s) that contributed most to the uplink utilization.

![Uplink port traffic per server](/public/img/utm/uplink_port_traffic_per_server.png)

**How to use**:  Select a UCS domain, FI (A or B) and an *Uplink* (Not the *Uplink Port Channel*). The RX and TX traffic graphs are auto-generated side-by-side along with the traffic breakdown per server. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of uplink. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - Displayed service profiles have vNIC/vHBA pinned to this uplink and hence, contributing to the traffic on this port.
  - Click on legends to sort according to the utilization.

You can select more than one value or All from *Uplink*. Looking at everything together can be useful when you don't know where to start or while doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one uplink at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: 
  - The displayed uplink utilization is slightly higher (1.1x) than the sum of the utilization of all servers to prevent overlapping in the graph. You can safely ignore this observation.
  - It is possible to display the traffic breakdown per vNIC/vHBA but that will make this graph too busy. Traffic breakdown at per vNIC/vHBA level is available on the page dedicated for server monitoring.

panels.title: FI-$fi_id $uplink traffic breakdown - TX
Uplink traffic distribution per service profile (Use 'Uplink')

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find uplink port-channel utilization (% and bits/s), member ports, and traffic distribution. In other words, verify the uniform utilization of all links in a port-channel.

![Uplink port-channel](/public/img/utm/uplink_port_channel.png)

**How to use**:  Select a UCS domain, FI (A or B), and a port-channel from the *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down. The RX and TX traffic graphs are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows aggregated speed of the port-channel. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - Displayed physical ports are the members of the port-channel. Verify their traffic rate and distribution.

You can select more than one value or All from *Uplink Port Channel*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for all the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know the root cause of the problem or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one port-channel at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: 
  - The displayed port-channel utilization is slightly higher than the sum of the utilization of all member ports. This is done to avoid overlapping in the graph by multiplying port-channel utilization by 1.1.  You can safely ignore this observation.
  - The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and FI (A or B)

Use ## for comments and # for configuration. ## The following names are reserved and should not be used (or ignored): ## id, tooltip, placeholder(s), link and label (see below) ## # ## Node label with placeholders and HTML. ## Default is '%name_of_first_column%'. # # label: %name%
%position%
Email # ## Node style (placeholders are replaced once). ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # style: label;image=%image%;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;rounded=1;fillColor=%fill%;strokeColor=%stroke%; # ## Parent style for nodes with child nodes (placeholders are replaced once). # # parentstyle: swimlane;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1; # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named style in styles. ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # stylename: - # ## JSON for named styles of the form {"name": "style", "name": "style"} where style is a cell style with ## placeholders that are replaced once. # # styles: - # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named label in labels. ## Default is the current label. # # labelname: - # ## JSON for named labels of the form {"name": "label", "name": "label"} where label is a cell label with ## placeholders. # # labels: - # ## Uses the given column name as the identity for cells (updates existing cells). ## Default is no identity (empty value or -). # # identity: - # ## Uses the given column name as the parent reference for cells. Default is no parent (empty or -). ## The identity above is used for resolving the reference so it must be specified. # # parent: - # ## Adds a prefix to the identity of cells to make sure they do not collide with existing cells (whose ## IDs are numbers from 0..n, sometimes with a GUID prefix in the context of realtime collaboration). ## Default is csvimport-. # # namespace: csvimport- # ## Connections between rows ("from": source colum, "to": target column). ## Label, style and invert are optional. Defaults are '', current style and false. ## If placeholders are used in the style, they are replaced with data from the source. ## An optional placeholders can be set to target to use data from the target instead. ## In addition to label, an optional fromlabel and tolabel can be used to name the column ## that contains the text for the label in the edges source or target (invert ignored). ## The label is concatenated in the form fromlabel + label + tolabel if all are defined. ## The target column may contain a comma-separated list of values. ## Multiple connect entries are allowed. # # connect: {"from": "manager", "to": "name", "invert": true, "label": "manages", \ # "style": "curved=1;endArrow=blockThin;endFill=1;fontSize=11;"} # connect: {"from": "refs", "to": "id", "style": "curved=1;fontSize=11;"} # ## Node x-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # left: # ## Node y-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # top: # ## Node width. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the width. Default is auto. # # width: auto # ## Node height. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the height. Default is auto. # # height: auto # ## Padding for autosize. Default is 0. # # padding: -12 # ## Comma-separated list of ignored columns for metadata. (These can be ## used for connections and styles but will not be added as metadata.) # # ignore: id,image,fill,stroke,refs,manager # ## Column to be renamed to link attribute (used as link). # # link: url # ## Spacing between nodes. Default is 40. # # nodespacing: 40 # ## Spacing between levels of hierarchical layouts. Default is 100. # # levelspacing: 100 # ## Spacing between parallel edges. Default is 40. Use 0 to disable. # # edgespacing: 40 # ## Name or JSON of layout. Possible values are auto, none, verticaltree, horizontaltree, ## verticalflow, horizontalflow, organic, circle or a JSON string as used in Layout, Apply. ## Default is auto. # # layout: auto # ## ---- CSV below this line. Default is no parent (empty or -). ## The identity above is used for resolving the reference so it must be specified. # # parent: - # ## Adds a prefix to the identity of cells to make sure they do not collide with existing cells (whose ## IDs are numbers from 0..n, sometimes with a GUID prefix in the context of realtime collaboration). ## Default is csvimport-. # # namespace: csvimport- # ## Connections between rows ("from": source colum, "to": target column). ## Label, style and invert are optional. targets.query: SELECT last("leadership") as "leadership" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIEnvStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "fi_id" = 'B') AND $timeFilter

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Verify uniform utilization of FI-A and FI-B. Also, the root cause of the traffic imbalance (if any).

![FI Load Balance](/public/img/utm/fi_lb.png)

**How to use**:  Select a UCS domain. The RX and TX traffic graphs over FI-A and FI-B are auto-generated side-by-side. This is calculated by sum of all FI uplink ports traffic. To use the output:
  - Verify that the utilization of FI-A and FI-B is uniform.
  - Refer to the graphs on the right to find the top servers consuming the bandwidth on FI-A and FI-B

targets.query: SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), fi_id fill(linear)

panels.title: Ingress traffic - Eth

panels.description: Top 10 servers consuming the uplink port bandwidth on FI-A

targets.query: select top("RX Traffic",10) as "RX Traffic",domain,chassis,service_profile from (SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX Traffic" FROM "autogen"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth' and fi_id='A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY service_profile fill(linear))

panels.title: FI-A Ingress traffic distribution - Eth (top 10 in Gbps)

panels.description: Top 10 servers consuming the uplink port bandwidth on FI-A

targets.query: select top("RX Traffic",10) as "RX Traffic",domain,chassis,service_profile from (SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX Traffic" FROM "autogen"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth' and fi_id='B') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY service_profile fill(linear))

panels.title: FI-B Ingress traffic distribution - Eth (top 10 in Gbps)

panels.description:

targets.query: SELECT sum("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), fi_id fill(linear)

panels.title: Egress traffic - Eth

panels.description:
Top servers consuming the uplink port bandwidth on FI-A

*Note* : This donut chart is showing the same data as the above bar charts - 2 different types of visualizations. Feel free to customize it.

targets.query: SELECT sum("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth' and fi_id='A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time(1m), service_profile fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-A Egress traffic distribution - Eth

panels.description:

targets.query: SELECT last("leadership") as "leadership" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIEnvStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "fi_id" = 'B') AND $timeFilter

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Verify uniform utilization of FI-A and FI-B. Also, the root cause of the traffic imbalance (if any).

![FI Load Balance](/public/img/utm/fi_lb.png)

**How to use**:  Select a UCS domain. The RX and TX traffic graphs over FI-A and FI-B are auto-generated side-by-side. This is calculated by sum of all FI uplink ports traffic. To use the output:
  - Verify that the utilization of FI-A and FI-B is uniform.
  - Refer to the graphs on the right to find the top servers consuming the bandwidth on FI-A and FI-B

targets.query: SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), fi_id fill(linear)

panels.title: Inbound traffic - FC

panels.description: Top 10 servers consuming the uplink port bandwidth on FI-A

targets.query: select top("RX Traffic",10) as "RX Traffic",domain,chassis,service_profile from (SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX Traffic" FROM "autogen"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC' and fi_id='A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY service_profile fill(linear))

panels.title: FI-A Inbound traffic distribution - FC (top 10 in Gbps)

panels.description: Top 10 servers consuming the uplink port bandwidth on FI-A

targets.query: select top("RX Traffic",10) as "RX Traffic",domain,chassis,service_profile from (SELECT sum("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "RX Traffic" FROM "autogen"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC' and fi_id='B') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY service_profile fill(linear))

panels.title: FI-B Inbound traffic distribution - FC (top 10 in Gbps)

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Verify uniform utilization of FI-A and FI-B. Also, the root cause of the traffic imbalance (if any).

![FI Load Balance](/public/img/utm/fi_lb.png)

**How to use**:  Select a UCS domain. The RX and TX traffic graphs over FI-A and FI-B are auto-generated side-by-side. This is calculated by sum of all FI uplink ports traffic. To use the output:
  - Verify that the utilization of FI-A and FI-B is uniform.
  - Refer to the graphs on the right to find the top servers consuming the bandwidth on FI-A and FI-B

targets.query: SELECT sum("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), fi_id fill(linear)

panels.title: Outbound traffic - FC

panels.description:
Top servers consuming the uplink port bandwidth on FI-A

*Note* : This donut chart is showing the same data as the above bar charts - 2 different types of visualizations. Feel free to customize it.

targets.query: select last(sum) from (SELECT sum("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]  FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC' and fi_id='A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time([[polling_interval]]s), service_profile fill(linear)) group by service_profile

SELECT sum("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "autogen"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC' and fi_id='A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time(1m), service_profile fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-A Outbound traffic distribution - FC

panels.description:
Top servers consuming the uplink port bandwidth on FI-A

*Note* : This donut chart is showing the same data as the above bar charts - 2 different types of visualizations. Feel free to customize it.

targets.query: SELECT sum("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC' and fi_id='B') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time(1m), service_profile fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-B Outbound traffic distribution - FC

panels.description: ![Uplink port traffic](/public/img/utm/fi_uplink_ports.png)

targets.query: SELECT (mean("bytes_rx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]])/(last(oper_speed)*1000000000)*100 as "% RX", mean("bytes_rx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]] as "RX", (mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]])/(last(oper_speed)*1000000000)*100 as "% TX", mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]] as "TX",sum("fcs_delta") as "FCS",sum("out_discard_delta") as "Out Discards" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("channel" != '' and "oper_state" = 'up' and "domain" =~ /^$domain$/ and transport='Eth') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY fi_id,port fill(linear)

panels.title: FI Eth Uplink Ports - utilization

panels.description: ![Uplink port traffic](/public/img/utm/fi_uplink_ports.png)

targets.query: SELECT (mean("bytes_rx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]])/(last(oper_speed)*1000000000*0.85)*100 as "% RX", mean("bytes_rx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]] as "RX", (mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]])/(last(oper_speed)*1000000000*0.85)*100 as "% TX", mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]] as "TX",sum("crc_rx_delta") as "CRC",sum("discard_rx_delta") as "RX Discards", sum("discard_tx_delta") as "TX Discards", sum("link_failures_delta") as "Link Failure", sum("signal_losses_delta") as "Signal Loss", sum("sync_losses_delta") as "Sync Loss"  FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("channel" != '' and "oper_state" = 'up' and "domain" =~ /^$domain$/ and transport='FC') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY fi_id,port fill(linear)

panels.title: FI FC Uplink Ports - utilization
Fabric Interconnect Uplink Port Traffic - Tabular view

targets.query: SELECT last("leadership") as "leadership" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIEnvStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "fi_id" = 'B') AND $timeFilter

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find uplink port utilization, traffic distribution, top-talkers, etc.

![Uplink port traffic](/public/img/utm/fi_uplink_ports.png)

**How to use**: Monitor the traffic pattern over time in the graph. Sort by clicking on the max or avg. Utilization of ports are stacked to show the total traffic on a FI. This can be changed by editing and de-selecting Stack under Display.

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]] AS "RX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth' AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/(mean("oper_speed")*1000000000*[[fc_data_rate]]) AS "TX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC' AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]]/(mean("oper_speed")*1000000000*[[fc_data_rate]]) AS "TX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "transport" = 'FC' AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'B') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

targets.query: SELECT (mean("bytes_rx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]])/(last(oper_speed)*1000000000*0.85)*100 as "% RX", mean("bytes_rx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]] as "RX", (mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]])/(last(oper_speed)*1000000000*0.85)*100 as "% TX", mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/ [[polling_interval]] as "TX",sum("fcs_delta") as "FCS", sum("out_discard_delta") as "Out Discards" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIServerPortStats" WHERE ("channel" != '' and "oper_state" = 'up' and "domain" =~ /^$domain$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY transport,fi_id,port fill(linear)

%position%
Email # ## Node style (placeholders are replaced once). ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # style: label;image=%image%;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;rounded=1;fillColor=%fill%;strokeColor=%stroke%; # ## Parent style for nodes with child nodes (placeholders are replaced once). # # parentstyle: swimlane;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1; # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named style in styles. ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # stylename: - # ## JSON for named styles of the form {"name": "style", "name": "style"} where style is a cell style with ## placeholders that are replaced once. # # styles: - # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named label in labels. ## Default is the current label. # # labelname: - # ## JSON for named labels of the form {"name": "label", "name": "label"} where label is a cell label with ## placeholders. # # labels: - # ## Uses the given column name as the identity for cells (updates existing cells). ## Default is no identity (empty value or -). # # identity: - # ## Uses the given column name as the parent reference for cells. Default is no parent (empty or -). ## The identity above is used for resolving the reference so it must be specified. # # parent: - # ## Adds a prefix to the identity of cells to make sure they do not collide with existing cells (whose ## IDs are numbers from 0..n, sometimes with a GUID prefix in the context of realtime collaboration). ## Default is csvimport-. # # namespace: csvimport- # ## Connections between rows ("from": source colum, "to": target column). ## Label, style and invert are optional. Defaults are '', current style and false. ## If placeholders are used in the style, they are replaced with data from the source. ## An optional placeholders can be set to target to use data from the target instead. ## In addition to label, an optional fromlabel and tolabel can be used to name the column ## that contains the text for the label in the edges source or target (invert ignored). ## The label is concatenated in the form fromlabel + label + tolabel if all are defined. ## The target column may contain a comma-separated list of values. ## Multiple connect entries are allowed. # # connect: {"from": "manager", "to": "name", "invert": true, "label": "manages", \ # "style": "curved=1;endArrow=blockThin;endFill=1;fontSize=11;"} # connect: {"from": "refs", "to": "id", "style": "curved=1;fontSize=11;"} # ## Node x-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # left: # ## Node y-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # top: # ## Node width. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the width. Default is auto. # # width: auto # ## Node height. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the height. Default is auto. # # height: auto # ## Padding for autosize. Default is 0. # # padding: -12 # ## Comma-separated list of ignored columns for metadata. (These can be ## used for connections and styles but will not be added as metadata.) # # ignore: id,image,fill,stroke,refs,manager # ## Column to be renamed to link attribute (used as link). # # link: url # ## Spacing between nodes. Default is 40. # # nodespacing: 40 # ## Spacing between levels of hierarchical layouts. Default is 100. # # levelspacing: 100 # ## Spacing between parallel edges. Default is 40. Use 0 to disable. # # edgespacing: 40 # ## Name or JSON of layout. Possible values are auto, none, verticaltree, horizontaltree, ## verticalflow, horizontalflow, organic, circle or a JSON string as used in Layout, Apply. ## Default is auto. # # layout: auto # ## ---- CSV below this line. panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find FI server port utilization, top-talkers, traffic distribution among ports, and among the two FI, etc.

![FI Server Ports](/public/img/utm/fi_server_ports.png)

**How to use**: Monitor the traffic pattern over time in the graph. Sort by clicking on the max or avg. The utilization of ports are stacked to show the combined traffic to/from a chassis. Ideally, all ports connected to the same chassis/IOM should have uniform traffic utilization.

**Details**: TX traffic on FI server ports is ingress to servers. Similarly, RX traffic on FI server ports is egress from servers.

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_rx_delta")  *8/ [[polling_interval]] AS "RX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIServerPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/  AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),port,peer_chassis,peer_slot,peer_port fill(linear)

Use ## for comments and # for configuration. ## The following names are reserved and should not be used (or ignored): ## id, tooltip, placeholder(s), link and label (see below) ## # ## Node label with placeholders and HTML. ## Default is '%name_of_first_column%'. # # label: %name%
%position%
Email # ## Node style (placeholders are replaced once). ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # style: label;image=%image%;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;rounded=1;fillColor=%fill%;strokeColor=%stroke%; # ## Parent style for nodes with child nodes (placeholders are replaced once). # # parentstyle: swimlane;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1; # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named style in styles. ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # stylename: - # ## JSON for named styles of the form {"name": "style", "name": "style"} where style is a cell style with ## placeholders that are replaced once. # # styles: - # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named label in labels. ## Default is the current label. # # labelname: - # ## JSON for named labels of the form {"name": "label", "name": "label"} where label is a cell label with ## placeholders. # # labels: - # ## Uses the given column name as the identity for cells (updates existing cells). ## Default is no identity (empty value or -). # # identity: - # ## Uses the given column name as the parent reference for cells. Default is no parent (empty or -). ## The identity above is used for resolving the reference so it must be specified. # # parent: - # ## Adds a prefix to the identity of cells to make sure they do not collide with existing cells (whose ## IDs are numbers from 0..n, sometimes with a GUID prefix in the context of realtime collaboration). ## Default is csvimport-. # # namespace: csvimport- # ## Connections between rows ("from": source colum, "to": target column). ## Label, style and invert are optional. Defaults are '', current style and false. ## If placeholders are used in the style, they are replaced with data from the source. ## An optional placeholders can be set to target to use data from the target instead. ## In addition to label, an optional fromlabel and tolabel can be used to name the column ## that contains the text for the label in the edges source or target (invert ignored). ## The label is concatenated in the form fromlabel + label + tolabel if all are defined. ## The target column may contain a comma-separated list of values. ## Multiple connect entries are allowed. # # connect: {"from": "manager", "to": "name", "invert": true, "label": "manages", \ # "style": "curved=1;endArrow=blockThin;endFill=1;fontSize=11;"} # connect: {"from": "refs", "to": "id", "style": "curved=1;fontSize=11;"} # ## Node x-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # left: # ## Node y-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # top: # ## Node width. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the width. Default is auto. # # width: auto # ## Node height. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the height. Default is auto. # # height: auto # ## Padding for autosize. Default is 0. # # padding: -12 # ## Comma-separated list of ignored columns for metadata. (These can be ## used for connections and styles but will not be added as metadata.) # # ignore: id,image,fill,stroke,refs,manager # ## Column to be renamed to link attribute (used as link). # # link: url # ## Spacing between nodes. Default is 40. # # nodespacing: 40 # ## Spacing between levels of hierarchical layouts. Default is 100. # # levelspacing: 100 # ## Spacing between parallel edges. Default is 40. Use 0 to disable. # # edgespacing: 40 # ## Name or JSON of layout. Possible values are auto, none, verticaltree, horizontaltree, ## verticalflow, horizontalflow, organic, circle or a JSON string as used in Layout, Apply. ## Default is auto. # # layout: auto # ## ---- CSV below this line. First line are column names. ---- name,position,id,location,manager,email,fill,stroke,refs,url,image Evan Miller,CFO,emi,Office 1,,me@example.com,#dae8fc,#6c8ebf,,https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-9-2-128.png Edward Morrison,Brand Manager,emo,Office 2,Evan Miller,me@example.com,#d5e8d4,#82b366,,https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-10-3-128.png Ron Donovan,System Admin,rdo,Office 3,Evan Miller,me@example.com,#d5e8d4,#82b366,"emo,tva",https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-2-128.png Tessa Valet,HR Director,tva,Office 4,Evan Miller,me@example.com,#d5e8d4,#82b366,,https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-3-128.png

targets.query: SELECT last("leadership") as "leadership" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIEnvStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "fi_id" = 'B') AND $timeFilter

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find ingress corrupted packets reported due to CRC mismatch

**How to use**:  CRC errors are always bad. Any non-zero reported values should be troubleshooted and resolved.

**Details**: There are many reasons for CRC errors. Most common are faulty SFP, cables, etc.

targets.query: SELECT mean("crc_rx_delta") AS "RX CRC" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-A per port CRC

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find ingress corrupted packets reported due to CRC mismatch

**How to use**:  CRC errors are always bad. Any non-zero reported values should be troubleshooted and resolved.

**Details**: There are many reasons for CRC errors. Most common are faulty SFP, cables, etc.

targets.query: SELECT mean("crc_rx_delta") AS "RX CRC" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'B') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-B per port CRC

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find packets discarded in RX direction

**How to use**:  Discards are always bad. Any non-zero reported values should be troubleshooted and resolved.

**Details**: There are many reasons for discards. Refer to the documentation for more details.

targets.query: SELECT mean("discard_rx_delta") AS "RX Discard" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-B per port TX Discards

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Various errors on Fibre Channel Ports

**How to use**:  It is fine for these counters to increment when the link is coming up but after that these counters should not increment. Packets may be dropped due to these errors.

**Details**: Refer to the documentation for details.

targets.query: SELECT mean("link_failures_delta") AS "Link Failures", mean("signal_losses_delta") AS "Signal Losses", mean("sync_losses_delta") AS "Sync Losses" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

panels.title: FI-A per port Link failures, Signal losses and Sync losses

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find packets discarded in Out direction

**How to use**:  Discards are always bad. Any non-zero reported values should be troubleshooted and resolved.

**Details**: There are many reasons for discards. Refer to the documentation for more details.

Out Discards are reported for Eth ports while TX Discards are reported for FC ports.

targets.query: SELECT mean("out_discard_delta") AS "Out Discard" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIUplinkPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "channel" != '' AND fi_id = 'A') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,port fill(linear)

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Monitor congestion against ingress traffic on FI Server Ports.

![Server Ports RX PAUSE](/public/img/utm/fi_server_port_rx_pause.png)

**How to use**:  The PAUSE frames on FI Server Ports are sent by the connected devices (FEX, IOM, or Servers) when they must apply back pressure on the incoming traffic. *Note*: Server Ingress traffic is TX for FI Server Ports and RX for FI Uplink Ports.

PAUSE frames may be exchanged under normal conditions also. So, find unusual PAUSE frame activity with below symptoms (not an exhaustive list):
- PAUSE frame rate in tens or hundreds per second is bad. Thousands, tens-of-thousands, or Millions per second is terribly bad.
- Look for spike in PAUSE frame rate. Low stable values are probably fine.
- Does one among many others has higher PAUSE frame activity?

Once you have a suspect Server Port,  continue digging further into FI > FEX/IOM/Chassis > Service profile. You can also go to the Detailed Congestion Monitoring dashboard.

**Details**: 
- A server sends PAUSE frames if it is unable to receive the traffic at the ingress rate. These frames are reported as RX PAUSE on the connected port (on FI or FEX or IOM). 
- PAUSE frames are used for FC traffic only (no-drop class). Congestion in Eth traffic is generally indicated by frame drops.

targets.alias: RX PAUSE on FI-A Server port $tag_port from $tag_peer
targets.query: SELECT non_negative_difference(mean("pause_rx"))/[[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "PAUSE against Inbound Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIServerPortStats" WHERE "domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND fi_id = 'A' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),port,peer,fi_id fill(linear)

panels.title: PAUSE against ingress traffic on server ports - FI-A

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Monitor congestion against ingress traffic on FI Server Ports.

![Server Ports RX PAUSE](/public/img/utm/fi_server_port_rx_pause.png)

**How to use**:  The PAUSE frames on FI Server Ports are sent by the connected devices (FEX, IOM, or Servers) when they must apply back pressure on the incoming traffic. *Note*: Server Ingress traffic is TX for FI Server Ports and RX for FI Uplink Ports.

PAUSE frames may be exchanged under normal conditions also. So, find unusual PAUSE frame activity with below symptoms (not an exhaustive list):
- PAUSE frame rate in tens or hundreds per second is bad. Thousands, tens-of-thousands, or Millions per second is terribly bad.

- Does one among many others has higher PAUSE frame activity?

Once you have a suspect Server Port,  continue digging further into FI > FEX/IOM/Chassis > Service profile. You can also go to the Detailed Congestion Monitoring dashboard.

**Details**: 
- A server sends PAUSE frames if it is unable to receive the traffic at the ingress rate. These frames are reported as RX PAUSE on the connected port (on FI or FEX or IOM). 
- PAUSE frames are used for FC traffic only (no-drop class). Congestion in Eth traffic is generally indicated by frame drops.

targets.alias: RX PAUSE on FI-B Server port $tag_port from $tag_peer
targets.query: SELECT non_negative_difference(mean("pause_rx"))/[[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "PAUSE against Inbound Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIServerPortStats" WHERE "domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND fi_id = 'B' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),port,peer,fi_id fill(linear)

panels.title: PAUSE against ingress traffic on server ports - FI-B

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Monitor congestion against egress traffic on FI Server Ports.

![Server Ports TX PAUSE](/public/img/utm/fi_server_port_tx_pause.png)

**How to use**:  The PAUSE frames on FI Server Ports are sent to the connected devices (FEX, IOM or Servers) when the backpressure must be applied against the outgoing traffic. *Note*: Server egress traffic is RX for FI Server Ports and TX for FI Uplink Ports.

PAUSE frames may be exchanged under normal conditions also. So, find unusual PAUSE frame activity with below symptoms (not an exhaustive list):
- PAUSE frame rate in tens or hundreds per second is bad. Thousands, tens-of-thousands, or Millions per second is terribly bad.
- Look for spike in PAUSE frame rate. Low stable values are probably fine.
- Does one among many others has higher PAUSE frame activity?

Once you have a suspect location,  continue digging further into FI > FEX/IOM/Chassis > Service profile. You can also go to the Detailed Congestion Monitoring dashboard.

**Details**: 
- A server receives PAUSE frames if it is transmitting data faster than the receiver can accept it. These frames are reported as TX PAUSE on the connected port (on FI or FEX or IOM). 
- PAUSE frames are used for FC traffic only (no-drop class). Congestion in Eth traffic is generally indicated by frame drops.

targets.alias: RX PAUSE on FI-A Server port $tag_port from $tag_peer
targets.query: SELECT non_negative_difference(mean("pause_tx"))/[[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "PAUSE against Outbound Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIServerPortStats" WHERE "domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND fi_id = 'A' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),port,peer,fi_id fill(linear)

panels.title: PAUSE against egress traffic on server ports - FI-A

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Monitor congestion against egress traffic on FI Server Ports.

![Server Ports TX PAUSE](/public/img/utm/fi_server_port_tx_pause.png)

PAUSE frames may be exchanged under normal conditions also. So, find unusual PAUSE frame activity with below symptoms (not an exhaustive list):
- PAUSE frame rate in tens or hundreds per second is bad. Thousands, tens-of-thousands, or Millions per second is terribly bad.
- Look for spike in PAUSE frame rate. Low stable values are probably fine.

Once you have a suspect location,  continue digging further into FI > FEX/IOM/Chassis > Service profile. You can also go to the Detailed Congestion Monitoring dashboard.

**Details**: 
- A server receives PAUSE frames if it is transmitting data faster than the receiver can accept it. These frames are reported as TX PAUSE on the connected port (on FI or FEX or IOM). 
- PAUSE frames are used for FC traffic only (no-drop class). Congestion in Eth traffic is generally indicated by frame drops.

targets.alias: RX PAUSE on FI-B Server port  $tag_port from $tag_peer
targets.query: SELECT non_negative_difference(mean("pause_tx"))/[[polling_interval]]/([[__interval_ms]]/([[polling_interval]] * 1000)) AS "PAUSE against Outbound Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIServerPortStats" WHERE "domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND fi_id = 'B' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),port,peer,fi_id fill(linear)
